div.p: Manually ddd latest Node 12 NodeSource APT repository; includes NPM; If you do not do this, you will likely install a much older version of Node. To check if installed: `node -v`

div.p: ~ is a place holder for the home directory, in Ubuntu it's /home/jj. It's best to use an actual path name as I ran into an instance once, somewhere, where I needed a hard coded path.

div.div:
If you receive an error:
E: Could not get lock /var/lib/dpkg/lock-frontend - open (11: Resource temporarily unavailable)
E: Unable to acquire the dpkg frontend lock (/var/lib/dpkg/lock-frontend), is another process using it?
You could wait it out as its likely a daily updater running if you are spinning up a new server
orFind the process using this with:
`sudo lsof /var/lib/dpkg/lock-frontend`
& to kill it:
`sudo kill -9 <PID>

div.div: I was going to paste the whole configuration file here, but I figure its easiest to just download from my github, and do a different chart for nginx config later. An important adjustment I do here is place my nginx conf files in the same conf.d folder, and disregard the nginx default way of doing things, which is two separate folders for "sites-available" & "sites-enabled".

switch.text: I was going to paste the whole configuration file here,...

div.div:
Goals:
Setup new user
Install up to date Node.js
Install Necessary Packages
Download config files and setup nginx
Serve a node application on port 3000 via nginx reverse proxy
Serve a direct link file share
Serve a static index page

div.div:
`add-apt-repository` is a Python script that adds a repository to `/etc/apt/sources.list` or `/etc/apt/sources.list.d`.
PPA is Personal Package Archives, a service that allows users to upload Ubuntu source packages. This creates a new file under /etc/apt/sources.list.d/ directory. A PPA repository public key will be downloaded and registered, and you can install with the next command; Certbot is constantly under development so we want the latest version.
